content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												This game is fantastic. It has minor flaws, but those didn't stop me from 100%-ing it over the course of three days, and now I'm very much looking forward to playing the bonus stuff and NG+.But anyway, let me detail why this game is great.First of all, the graphics are not just pixely, they are actually stylized very well after a real 8-bit game, which many "retro" game authors don't do. Technically I suppose there are things that a NES couldn't do in this game (some bosses are huge, sometimes there's many sprites at once, etc), but it sets the tone perfectly in my opinion. Doesn't hurt that it all looks nice by itself.The music is great, too, not simple generic chiptune stuff, it's actually very memorable, gets stuck in your head, but doesn't detract from the gameplay, instead enhancing it by adding a lot to the atmosphere. My favorite tunes are the last area's and the cave's. And the boss music is awesome too!The atmosphere is top notch. The game doesn't take itself too seriously, but it pretends to. It has a lot of easter eggs and references, but they are somehow done very unobtrusively and I never thought that they distracted from the immersion as they often do when done hamfistedly. If you like the mood of those old castle-featuring NES games, you're gonna get that and more.The controls are damn near flawless. Your character is pretty mobile, perfectly responsive and everything bad that happens to you is usually your fault.The gameplay is addicting. It gets hard, very challenging in fact, but 99% of the time it's fair.There's some exploits for the bosses making them pretty easy if you know the right spell to use (there's one that kills pretty much every boss insanely fast...), but they're still mostly pretty fun. The platforming will keep you on your toes but none of it is obloxiously hard. It's very refreshing and keeps you engaged even when you have to retrace large sections of the game with shiny new items or abilities - the enemies are much easier when you return, making it fun to slash them all apart with ease, but the platforming is still respectably dangerous but not overly specific or complex. This makes it fun to backtrack.The layout is sort of linear, unlike a typical metroidvania: this game is sturctured more linearly, with a single linear path from start to finish and diverging dead ends with goodies (many of which you won't be able to access on your first run through the world). And there's several quick travel waypoints. This makes backtracking very manageable. I tend to dread having to comb a world of a metroidvania after getting a bunch of abilities, because it's often a chore. However, in this game you won't easily forget some random corner somewhere and forever forget to check it. It's really easy, for example, to get through almost the entire game again after you get the double jump and find all the places that were just too high. There's some unique stuff you should memorize the location of, but that's easy too. In conclusion, the exploration aspect is very light but very fun.There's a whole bunch of secrets and all of them are really fun to discover, too. Some make you feel clever even when it's simple stuff.Overall, pretty much everything about this game is done well and it's definitely worth a playthrough or several. If I were to pick it apart and mention some flaws, I would only be able to find minor things: a few magic spells seem to be entirely useless, some equipment parts as well (over the course of the game I found like three swords while already having better ones). Some pre-boss cutscenes are unskippable. That's pretty much it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												This game is a gem and a firm reminder of something I've missed from games for a long time.  The ability to control when and how often I save.  Too often I find games that auto-save so bloody often that it winds up saving when I don't want it to.  Get a crap drop from a boss?  It autosaved, gotta start over.  Autosaving may seem like such a convenient thing, but when a game actually has missable achievements, collectables, quests, etc, autosaving can become a rather costly convenience.  Or, to put it more simply, it turns from a blessing to a curse.Which is why I'm glad games like Castle in the Darkness can remind us of our roots, where the game doesn't save until you tell it to.  No relying on autosaves, no quicksave/quickload.  No, you're on our own.  This game is hard, almost brutally so in some areas (Torture Chamber comes quickly to mind), but it's the kind of difficulty I often like.  Memorization, skill based, platforming challenges at it's purest.  Sure, there's cheap shots occasionally, but they occur more towards the end of the game, when it's throwing everything it has at you, or in challenging little puzzle rooms for great items.  Getting to 100% completion itself is a daunting task, but a managable one.  Most people here have said they had hundreds of deaths and you will too; I beat the game 100% with a little over 200 deaths.And my GOD, this soundtrack!  There are a great many places I wound up going back to and just running the game in the background so I can listen to the music.  Sure, you can get the OST from Matt Kap's bandcamp page for $3, which I think is a little overpriced (Seriously, you're selling your game for $6 and $3 for the soundtrack?  Jake Kaufman, who did the soundtracks for the Shantae games and Double Dragon Neon, amongst many others, gives his away for free.) compared to the game itself.  Sure, it's a very small amount of money, but in terms of percentages, yeesh.  Seriously, 50%?  Anyways, I highly recommend the track for the Grand Hall the most, it's amazing.This game beautifully marries old school platforming and music with more modern, open world exploration, to some extent.  You can go anywhere just about anytime, and while the game is more or less a straight line until you get a hold of the double jump, you can go just about anywhere for little bonus items that make other areas easier.  For example, you can get a fantastic spell from the House of Ruth pretty early on (In fact, I'd say you're an idiot if you don't get this optional spell since it helps out SO MUCH).  Just go inside, go long the lower path and, when it splits, go right.  You should find a massive chest with the spell, Energy Splash, inside it.  Think of it like a chargable shotgun blast, with that kind of spread.  Oh, and it's considerably more powerful than the Fireball spell you'll have at the time.  In fact, that spell was almost broken and I never used any other spell for most of the game, except when required, at least until Gale Wind became available to me.Even better, this game is smart with the spells, where certain magic and attacks do nothing to certain enemies while others wreck them completely.  I've had bosses get nuked from, say, the Soul Blazer spell when a technically superior spell, like Gale Wind, does nothing.  I appreciate this, as it encourages the player to experiment and not play so safely with the same old spells.  Some weaknesses are obvious (Like the Ice Golems when you should only have the Fireball and Energy Splash spells...) and others are not (Killing the Red Ogre that flings lightning with his own reflected shots gets you the Thunderblast spell.  I just saved you, like, an hour trying to find that last bloody spell.)But if there's one piece of criticism I have to launch, it's that this game is a little too old school.  You can only change our gear at save points, which is a very odd choice, since there will be times you go to fight a boss and be completely unprepared for the battle, perhaps even having on a spell and weapon combination that actually cannot harm the boss itself.  I myself got hit by this numerous times, so not being able to hit a button to change gear and spells was more annoying that anything else.  Secondly, this game has no pause button.  Oh, it'll pause if you click on another screen to look something up or answer an email or the like, but the button to unpause does nothing after you press it.  Just because games like Titanfall and Dark Souls can't pause doesn't mean the pause feature is no longer a good idea.  Pausing isn't needed for those games because of the multiplayer element.  This game, however, is a single player game with no online mode or features to speak of.  Not having a pause button, especially in a game that's essentially a huge love letter to old school gaming, is a freaking sin.And finally, the lack of a map.  Now, old school games weren't known for their maps, but you know what is?  Castlevania: Symphony of the Night.  And this game gets referenced a TON in Castle in the Darkness.  Also, old school games didn't typically need a map since old school games were relatively short, with very few exceptions, like Metroid.  And given the number of secret rooms, many of which housing important items, this game would have benefitted so much from a map system.  ESPECIALLY when it comes to conveyance.I assume you all are familiar with the term after that one Egoraptor video.  For those not in the know, it means how well something gives you direction and purpose.  The map of Castle in the Darkness is so huge that it's hard to figure out where to go and what to do, especially when you reach a point where you're missing one very good spell, X-Sword.  Eventually, after exhausting all possible leads and finding more secret passages than you can count, you MIGHT figure out that you can actually GO TO THE RIGHT IN THE WARP ROOM!  You know, that one room where you can choose which statue to warp to?  You can goto the right.  And there's a bit of an area to explore, then, if you have a certain item, you can enter the Crystal Tower, which contains not one, or two, but THREE bosses.  Two of which give HP upgrades (+1 each) and the last giving the completely broken X-Sword spell.  Oh, and there's also another item, the Elixir, to get here, which gives a massive +5 HP upgrade.Also, if I may ask a question of the developer; What is the sixth teleporter statue for?  Because there's only five teleporters in the game.  Are you going to add some additional content via DLC?  Because that would be interesting.Anyways, if I had to give this game a score, I'd give it an 8/10.  The game is fantastic and other than some minor annoyances with the controls, lack of a pause button, and the lack of a map, it's well worth anybody's time.  Just be ready to die a lot.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												TLDR: Even though the metroidvania gameplay is great, absolutely do not buy this game unless you enjoy ludicriously difficult platforming (which often means replaying the same stretch of level thirty times). You should also be okay with the game killing you with "prank" deaths and insta-death cheap shots. This game is full of that sh** and it does it more and more as you get further into it.What do I mean by "prank" deaths and cheap shots? Here are a few examples:Early in the game you find a Mario style pipe sticking out of the ground. There is a sign beside it that says "Stay out of the sewer pipe!" So naturally you jump into the sewer pipe. It's just a narrow tube that drops you directly onto a bed of spikes. [developertrollface.jpeg]There is a cave in the game made of jagged grey rocks. As you're climbing a jagged upward slope, the devs put a single grey spike right in the middle of the slope, completely blended in with the rocks. What, you didn't see the deliberately camouflaged spike and accidentally touched it and insta-died? [developertrollface.jpeg]Not to mention the countless, countless, countless times that, spikes fall from the ceiling and instantly kill you. Sometimes you can see them and avoid them, if you remember to look for it, constantly, at all possible times. But also sometimes they'll just fall from beyond the top edge of the screen somewhere like the p*ssed off hand of god deciding that, no, actually, your life is over now, because f*** you that's why. [developertrollface.jpeg]I ultimately got too p*ssed at this game and decided not to finish it. I recommend this game because the metroidvania elements really ARE good, but the prank deaths and the meatboy bulls*** ruined it for me. But if you like that sort of thing, then you're gonna love this. FAIR WARNING, though, for people who just want the metroidvania but aren't into the uber difficult platformer fad.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												I'll start this by saying that it's a simple game, for people who don't want super flashy systems, and just want that old-school action platformer feel again. It has amazingly simplistic controls of 6 buttons (4 movement keys, attack, jump) and feels totally natural to play on a controller.This game will kill you. A lot. Not all these deaths will be fair, and some will be more than frustrating. Many will also be amazingly pathetic, and you'll wonder why you just did that (like walking into a room, and then walking straight into spikes for no particular reason)The game has an almost non-existant fast travel system (about 5 points throughout the game that you can only warp to, from one of the other points) and saving is limited to only set points, with no version of auto-save on boss kill. This means if you die after killing a boss, but before saving, you have to kill the boss again. Sometimes the lack of fast-travel access bugs me, but overall you live with it.This may be sounding a bit of a negative review overall, but honestly, it's not. Nothing takes too long to do again if you die (To the extent that I've died, respawned, and died to that same thing within seconds because I was playing stupidly) so you're never sitting there thinking "There goes 4 hours of my time."The developer also has a wonderful response time to issues, and isn't afraid to let people play their way. A Bug was found allowing access to an area much earlier than intended, but would prevent anyone who did so from getting back out. When the dev fixed this, they fixed it by letting players get back out, not by preventing them from getting in early. Which means for the most part, if you see something you can only do with that pixel perfect jump timing, while it may not be intended, it likely won't be patched out just because "it's not how you're supposed to play."

This game seems to be stuck in Windowed mode (edit you can change the setting in options), so if that bothers you i would pass on this for now. Running Windows 8.1 and an Nvidea 745M graphics card if that helps anyone else having difficulty getting this to work.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												What is Castle in the Darkness?A fast-paced action platformer with metroidvania elements. I do think enough to call it a metroidvania, but its areas are relatively linear with a few side-paths and the whole game is basically a left-to-right quest with extra dungeons tucked away.And really, it's pretty great. The character speed is fast and the combat is fast, leading to a very high-energy playing experience. Only in later/harder parts of the game does dying really feel that consequential, before then checkpoints are frequent and reloading is simple and easy if you die. It's fun to die, it really is.The game pulls some traps and a few puzzles but for the most part it's straightforward platforming and poking enemies with your sword or using one of the variety of spells. You gain more HP for each boss you kill and gain better weapons and armor as the game progresses, plus you can find some really strong gear hidden away in one of the many bonus dungeons. Until you get your double jump there are a lot of inaccessible goodies, leading to some backtracking to find them all, but you can warp between areas and there's never a huge massive distance between warps given the fast-pace of the game.At times there are a few spots where checkpoints seem a little far apart, primarily in the last main area and in some of the hidden dungeons, but it's never really too far. There are however a few pretty rude traps that feel a little unfair. Not too many, though. The platforming is tight and the combat is designed such that you can avoid hits almost all the time if you play well, and you'll need to as even at max HP and defense your character is pretty squishy, to say nothing of how easy it is to die with the basic gear. There's a lot of game here too, for only $6; it took me 10 hours to 100% the game, and beyond that there's a NG+ with some extra items and a no-damage challenge (that I did not do). For the price, it's definitely a good amount of content. The art looks fine enough and the music is pretty good, as well. The bosses are pretty varied and each area tends to have some unique platforming to it as well. Overall? Definitely a good experience for anyone interested in metroidvanias or action platformers in general, I really enjoyed this little game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												From Nicalis, the same indie company that brought us Cave Story has dished out another 2D platform action adventure, this time from an American developer. As some descriptions of the game mention already, the game has a Metroidvania feel as you fight hordes of monsters from the Kingdom of Alexandria with the role of an unnamed hero.The challenge has a nice sweet spot for veteran gamers, and you'll often find yourself dying until you find your way out of a section as the game progresses. It's a nice treat for fans of platformers, and well worth the money.(SPOILER WARNING BELOW)As much fun with the game I had with the exploration, there are also nostalgia-based references throughout some of the game. If you're familiar with the NES game, Monster Party, you'll find a couple of faces that you're sure to point out immediately, and there's also the Vigo painting straight out of Ghostbusters II. But goofy references aside, I give this a buyers approval. It's not one to miss!

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
Product received for free
												This game is full of variety and takes you back to the retro days.  There are tons of bosses and secrets to discover. The developer also put a ton of secrets and references throughout the game.  The game is very tough but once you master the jump you become extremely good at the game.  All these people who complain about the instant death spikes I think are taking it over board.  Yes they kill you right away and there are one or two areas that just have them as a surprise but that's what they used to do in these games back in the day.  R-type 3 you basically had to memorize the entire game to beat it.  There are only 2 or 3 areas where this happens in this game so I think that isn't too bad.The music is awesome really well done.  I beat this and got all the secrets.  I even unlocked something in new game plus in which you have to go through 60% of the game without even being hit once.  I won't spoil the new mode you unlock but it just shows how much is there for like 5 bucks.  That said too, I played this for 47hours and I can go through the game without a hit.  So anyone can beat this game you just have to practice.I loved this game.  I wish there were more games like it. I recommend buying it you can't go wrong.

content:
Posted: February 26
												Despite all of the negative reviews, I highly enjoyed this game.  It was a decent throwback to the old NES classics and had some vintage old-school references sprinkled within it.  I beat this game and new game plus 100% with 333 deaths, so, looking at the death count, this game really isn't that difficult.  Surely, there are some annoying parts in the game where spikes fall on your head and one hit kills you, but that is something anyone should come to expect with a Matt Kap game.  Overall, my favorite part of the game was the music, secondary, the variety of environments, and lastly, the large amount of easter-eggs and other silly things going on.  Gameplay was solid.  Challenge was about a 6.5/10.  Overall score, I'd say about an 8.5.  I recommend it to anyone looking for a decent 2d platform with a little bit of bite!

content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
												Sluggish controller support, floaty inaccurate jumping, and no pause function (at all). A Metroid-style game that fails to understand what made Super Metroid a tight game with less awful backtracking. Instead there is sudden, massive backtracking through dull looking levels that are barely utilised by the low jumping height of the small character. I got to a point where I couldn't continue and was apparently expected to backtrack to who knows where for who knows what that was forever back, and I just thought "You're ♥♥♥♥ing kidding me?!" I'm not going back to this mess of a game. In a world where Super Metroid exists (and is still available, at that), a game so inferior (to such an old game) is completely unnecessary.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												Its difficult to make a critic of this game. If you like old school, this is for you, NO DOUBT. It has everything: all the references, easy controls, just three actions (attack, jump and magic), beautiful and different levels really well chained, and a terrific music that you will probably sing the whole day.BUT!Theres a really disappointing aspect in the level design: Last level is just unplayable. It changes from an old school to an "I wanna be the boshy" style. I felt it wasn't worth the effort. It just GETS BORING. And we are not talking about an "old-schools-were-this-way" issue. Nope. This is a bad level design. C'mon, I never played again after defeating the final boss. It's not worth the effort trying to jump over the infinite spikes once and again. The final boss was SO easy compared to spikes that I even felt cheated.Volgarr the viking is an extremely tough game, but I always come back and play, even just a first stage, or change to another stage and have a good fight. Same with first Castlevania, tough but lovely, challenging, magical,... great. But here, nah, I just got fed up. Better designed bosses, that deal with your ability to jump and attack would have been a way better idea. But jumping over spikes just got boring. Even in my worst Castlevania nightmares never faced that situation. NEVER get bored of all their unfair deaths. Even enjoyed the Dacula X, with the final fight over those columns. But here spikes make it just impossible. It becomes an "I wanna be the boshy", and thats NOT what i wanted. If I want that, i get Wings of Vi, which is really focused on unfair fighting to the point of making it beautiful.

												This game is... OK. I love this style of game, and I played this game because games in this style are rare, but honestly, I wouldn't recommend this game to most people. The game's high difficultly frankly makes it not very fun. I've played and enjoyed games harder than this; this game's problem is that it doesn't use its difficulty well. This brand of difficulty and exploration don't really mix well. The difficulty makes exploration really risky, and makes backtracking a pain.If you love this style of game as much as I do, you'll get some enjoyment out of it, but only when you've exhausted dozens of better games. If you don't, I can't recommend this game.

												Unfinished and buggy.I really wanted to like it, but it's broken, and effectively unplayable for me. On two different machines I got the same problems. Changing the window size crashes the game. It loads up at the last windows size selected, but it's a huge pain.on first load, the volume for everything is turned all the way to 00 for both music and sfx. X and C are your selection buttons for some reason, enter and esc do nothing. when I changed it to controller, it assigned BOTH jump and attack to 'button 88' which I manually changed. No big deal, but not confidence inspiring either."partial controller support" is accurate. It works for a few minutes then completely messes up. upon getting the first power up from the first boss, holding right on the controller when you get it will cause your player to become unresponsive and ONLY go right. You then get stuck on the first obstacle you should be able to jump over.  If I have to make sure I'm not touching anything on the controller when I get a power-up or it'll break the game, I won't be playing long. I got these problems on both an intel based and amd based system, initially with an xbox controller, and after with a steam controller. both were terrible experiences.I can't recommend this game until it is actually playable for me...

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												I am a fan of the metroidvania genre- I love games like Metroid, Castlevania, and Cave Story. This is definitely a metroidvania title. That said, I can not personally recommend it. The 8-bit artwork and animations look cheap while the story is boring and uninspired. The unique secret areas in the game are pretty much all just non-sequitor references to other games and have nothing to do with the story in Castle in the Darkness. The game is full of secrets but you will be very disappointed when you find them. While Castle in the Darkness certainly nails all the mechanics of what you would expect from a Metroidvania title- it feels like nothing more than an emulation or parody of those games.It could have been great but ultimately falls short of expectations.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2016
												Some games are retro in the best way, striving to be as good in reality as the games of past eras appear through rose tinted glasses. Some are labeled retro simply because they're 2D, even though their design and even visuals have nothing to do with older titles and probably wouldn't have been possible on the machines of the past.Some ape the forms and functions of older games in total. Castle in the Darkness is one of those, and the problem with it is that most of those games were, in fact, kinda♥♥♥♥♥♥Enemies with unclear hit boxes, bland color palette, small and undetailed sprites, deaths that can only be avoided by memorizing the locations of traps, bosses you can cheese by finding spots in their arenas they can't touch (but which are otherwise exercises in tedium, with tiny hitboxes you always have to jump to strike), no map and no sense of forward momentum. If you're devoted to the actuality of middling NES titles as well as the memory of them, you may find all of this charming. I found it, like the games it was attempting to evoke, a reminder of why we've left all this stuff behind, and why the very best titles like Mario and Mega Man generally didn’t have it to begin with.Castle in the Darkness would have been an okay game in the 80s, but we’re decades away from that being good enough for a commercial release.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												A game that prides itself on how unfair it can be with awkward controls, glidy movement, lazy mechanics, and unfair enemy design. it took me all of twenty minutes before I was so dissapointed I tried to return it. Now, before you talk about how I just don't like a challenge, I will inform you that I have a platimun in all of the souls games. I love a good challege. However, there is a difference between a challenging/difficult game, and an unfair game. The hitboxes on your character are huge, and those of the enemies hardly exist. I specifically remember one enemy who throws knives very early in the game. If you get hit twice by these knives you die, if you touch him, you're inta-killed, and this is the best part, you can only hit his head. So no body shots count. This guy runs back and forth, throwing knives everywhere, and you're lucky if you can land a hit. I died to this guy about 50 times, assumed the rest of the game would be no better as far as fair gameplay is concerned, and stopped playing.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
 7.5 / 10 - YOU WILL DIE A LOT And if you're okay with that, you'll have a great time with this game. If you liked Rogue LEgacy, you'll feel right at home with this game.  If You liked UnEpic, You will like this game. If you liked SHovel Knight. You will like this game.This game is old-school, in looks, mechanics and difficulty and that is it's pinnacle and it's pit at the same time. If you're not into precision platforming with combat mixed in. You'll likely find this game a nightmare. It does not pull punches and will not hold your hand.The controls are mercifully quite tight and responsive, at least playing with a keyboard as I am and the fights anrd puzzles are presented as challenges. The main problem is that lack of any guidance or instruction or hinting.  You have no way of knowing if the next screen is another regular room or a boss fight so while the game encourages exploration it mercilessly punisshes it from time to time.All in all High marks for this game. VBest enjoyed in 10-30 minute chunks.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												For 18 years I've waited for a sequel to my most beloved franchise, Castlevania. And as far as I can tell this is as good as I'm going to get. This is an incredibly well done platformer, one that me and the cats that frequent my balcony have taken to calling "Mega Man-Vania" If you're a fan of either franchise I urge you to jump on this, because neither of them seem to be on the verge of coming back any time soon. Gameplay is simple. You walk, you jump, you attack, maybe hold attack for a magic spell not unlike Mega Mans Mega Buster. I have noticed an issue of slowdown on some of the bosses thus far, though not game breaking it warrants a mention, it's most noteable on bosses. I've yet to see it break the game, but it may make you resort to some less than proud tactics. So far it hasn't been a gamebreaking issue however.If you enjoyed the NES-era Mega Man and Castlevania games this is certainly worth a look, especially at a paltry 6 dollars. As for people online comparing it to Dark Souls, they must be afflicted with an intellectual disability. I haven't seen one mechanic common to the two. Well it counts your deaths I guess. Thats the same. TLDR: CitD = Mega Man-Vania

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												I'll start by saying that the music is what sold me on this game through the store. It has some damn good tunes, at least for the genre. There are also a good number of areas to explore and items to collect. This has everything for the making of a truly great game... except it is quickly destroyed by the developers hubris. Games are supposed to be fun, not frustrating.No, this is not a rant about how difficult the game is. Truth be told, its not difficult at all. The actual GAME of the game, is fairly easy, but there is so much instant death and cheap trap placements, that skill is quickly thrown out the window in favor of memory, and THAT is why I cannot reccomend this game. It is fun to enter a new area and get as far as you can before you make one mistake too many. It is downright infuriating to enter the same area for the 30th time because you keep making one mistake. This wouldn't be as bad if the boss fights were worthwhile, but they aren't. Save for one, (not the final one) they are all pretty much a joke, many of them being references to other, better games. So in a sense its a few minutes of fun for several hours of frustration getting there. Not a good formula.Story-wise, well, some would argue a game like this dosn't need a story. The problem is, this game tries to put one in, and only goes half way. The best cinematic of the game is the introduction, then it adds cutscenes throughout the different game areas... until is just decides to give up on them and leave you guessing as to what is going on halfway through. This ends up in a narrative mess with much of the plot being unresolved (even with 100% completion). A rule of gaming when it comes to story is either go all the way, or don't go at all. Ninja Gaiden, Castlevania, Metroid, and other titles like them may not have had complex stories, but they paced the ones they did have and wrapped up all their loose ends. For a game that likes to make a lot of references, they should have actually taken a page from those games' development.And finally, the references themselves. Why? Why so many? And why so pointless? References can be fun, but not when they are hammering you upside the head every other screen. Yes, I fought the twin Hydra in Mario Bros. 2. I don't need to fight it AGAIN here. Yes, Navi was annoying in Ocarina of Time. You know what's more annoying? Your text box blocking my veiw when she hits me in your game. Some references are good, such as the shooting sword easter egg, and some of the "mirror" scenes like the entrance to the keep in castlevania, but most are just pointless, to the point you get absolutely sick of seeing them. Even worse, they remind you that those games were better, and why.I know I am absolutely hammering this game, which is a shame, because there were parts I like. But truth be told, without the music, it would just be another passable metroidvania game that errs on being too much like its rage game cousins.TL/DRA decent attempt at a metroidvania with some good music and decent early level gameplay. However late game is chock full of insta-death goodness and the tidal wave of nostalgiac refereces gets tiring quite quickly.    2/5

												This game is hard. But its not the stupid kind of hard like "I Wanna Be The Guy" is. Its good hard, its skill based hard. Every time you die, you know exactly what killed you and you know what you could have done to avoid it. Trust me, you will be dying a lot.The controls are very simple, though I dislike how there isn't a pause button. The two buttons are jump and attack, hold down the attack button for magic attacks. Your character moves at a good pace throughout the entire game, I wasn't getting impatient at how long it was taking to get anywhere until just before I got the warp stone, which makes everything MUCH easier. Save points are in good places as well.My favorite part of this game has to be the soundtrack. Where else can you find a chiptune rendition of Mute's song "Nevermore"?Two different endings, but I'mnot going to spoil the differences between the two or what you do to get either ending.Another great job by the Nicalis crew, specifically Matt Kap. Good job, man, really, really good job.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												This game masquerades as a fun challenge, when really it punishes the player for getting farther without picking up extra "secrets", a.k.a COMPLETELY NECESSARY GEAR, and does not allow the player to experience the fullness of the game that they rightfully paid for. There are hard games, and then there are stupid games that are trying way too hard to be "challenges" that a player must overcome. No. If I was allowed to go back into the previous areas to obtain the better gear with my new abilities, I could progress further with ease. Instead, I am stuck with a boss that is above and beyond any mere "difficulty" setting, which I could easily beat, were I allowed to leave my current area. Thank you, Castle in the Darkness, for making me want to experience the rest of your game so badly, that I spent needless hours on a boss that would be as difficult as a daisy with a dagger if only I were allowed to go back and use a simple double jump to aquire an item which would allow me access to gear far above and beyond the "Wrong" sword, thus allowing me to MAYBE experience the rest of the game I paid for. Really, thank you. DOn't waste your time. The challenge of the game is fake, and the acheivements are pretentious as well as empty, You get nothing for victories won via skill, and win with ease if you explore correctly at the exact right moment instead of forging ahead to face what lies before you, with no intruction as to when the right time is to explore, nor told that you will be stuck for eternity if you are to continue on to the impossible bosses without double jumping your way to victory in the first area. Screw this game and screw tryhard level designers.

number of helpful: 6 of 19 people (32%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												Based on the similarly retro aesthetic you may feel tempted to assume Castle in the Darkness is in the vein of Shovel Knight, another throwback platformer of recent times. That would be a mistake, because the two games have fundamentally different design philosophies. Shovel Knight aimed to emulate the games of old, but not copy them blindly; it included many modern touches that made it a stronger game overall. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said of Castle in the Darkness. Speaking plainly, I am not certain the developers understand why some trends in gaming have died. In seeking to emulate older platformers, this game simply adopts old design ideas without much apparent thought as to what works or doesn't. It is, fundamentally, a game of trial and error. Instant death spikes run rampant, there are no health pickups whatsoever, and your character has the endurance of wet toilet paper. On their own, none of those things are inherently negative, but combined they make for an experience that simply is not enjoyable. Frequent save points in another game would be an act of mercy. In Castle in the Darkness, they reek of lazy design: of the developers knowing exactly what is wrong with what makes their game difficult and not caring to fix those problems, instead using the many save points as a two-inch bandage over a gaping wound.To be clear, this review isn't me going "Waah, game too hard!"... I have no issue with games choosing to be difficult. The Souls games are among my favorite in existence for a variety of reasons, difficulty curve included. I don't care about games being hard, I care about WHY they are. A well-designed difficulty curve is a fantastic thing, worth notice precisely because it is not easy to make a game that is difficult for the right reasons. Unfortunately, this game is one of many that don't understand what those reasons are. If, knowing that, you want to give it a try more power to you.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												The level design is terrible. You need to save to keep your progress, but a lot of the time when you back-track from somewhere that is important (like a boss fight or getting an item) to a save point you end up dying and have to do it all over again (I kept having to fight a boss because there was a spike pit that was designed for the other direction in the way, and the jump was hard to make while back-tracking). The jumping mechanics take time to get used to (it feels like the gravity accelerates way too quickly).It's also extremely open-ended. There was one boss I fought that needed a certain spell to be beaten or else the fight was pretty much impossible, and the spell you need to beat it is all the way back in the starting place and you need double-jump to get it (which you should already have by the time you get to this boss, but the double-jump is much later in the game than Alexandria). I also had no indication or hints to use that spell on the boss. I already had the spell by the time I got to this boss, but I didn't think to use it because there were absolutely no hints or indicators that it should be used for that boss. The only possible hint I had was that the trajectory of the spell matched up with the boss, so I used it. If somebody else didn't see that spell -- or just forgot that it was there -- they'd have to look up a walkthrough or else they couldn't progress through the game. Except not really, because all I got from the bosses was an item called White Orb that does "?????". That's what it says it does in the inventory. I still don't know what it does, so as far as I know it was a waste of time to get. You gotta love this Simon's Quest nonsense.Honestly, I'm considering not finishing the game, because at least 75% of the deaths I've racked up were from cheap level design, and you have to keep repeating the same sections of the game over and over again.It has a lot of references to old NES games, and they all just reminded me that I could be playing a better game.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												I'm really sorry, but there is a fatal flaw in this game.  The spikes are just too much.  I get it in Super Meat Boy or 1001 Spikes, and I love those games.  Those games are **meant** to be tough platformers, and excel at that one thing.This game, however, does a REALLY good job as being an action adventure game with tons of really great bosses, enemies, power-ups, and weapons, a large open(ish) world, with lots of secrets and exploration.  That right there would have made the game a solid 9/10.  But the spikes, man ... just too much.  The game doesn't need it at all.  I'm having such exploring and slashing away and one sloppy jump has me repeating the same areas way too many times because of insta-kill spikes.  And that's fine.  If Kap wanted to make a tough platformer with lots of action/exploration elements, that's great, and he NAILS the action/exploration aspect of this game.  Where it fails for me, though, is the platforming/spikes/insta-kill.  It's too much for me to want to care anymore.This is really difficult for me to give this one a thumbs down, because it does so many things just spot on.  But I can't recommend a game that I just don't even care about enough to want to beat anymore.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												It isn't fun.You only heal at save spots. As the monsters don't drop healing, it requires a lot of boring play such as: I leave the room with the save spot, and I get hit by something...so, I walk back to the save spot. Repeatedly.  These save spots can be very distant.Without a map, there is no ability to plan backtracking.You gather a lot of money in this game, but there are few opportunities to spend it. Collision detection is very off with some bosses.The controls have some bad choices: there are some blocks that the player needs to press up when they break so they can jump further. There is no clue that a block is this type (which often leads to dying.. and a lot of redoing rooms to get back to that spot). Why the "up" button? The player's finger is already on the jump button. It is a metroidvanie game without the pieces that make it enjoyable. Too unforgiving. Too much redoing pointless rooms after a death to get back to challenging spots. Meh.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												I haven't played much yet but if you take games seriously you can already feel the multiple flaws that ruins the experience before you're even an hour in. I've played a lot of sidescroll/platformers over the years and I can say that this is not recommended until they patch the gameplay. From my perspective this feels like an easy money grab from the devs because I don't see how they would even dare release this game if they actually play tested it internally. Again, this game has potential if they fix it but in it's  current state it is a disaster.Where to even start with this mess. The movement (jumping, moving and combat) is unacceptable quality for a game that isn't more than 50 megabytes. The acceleration is unnintuitive and the response time is poor. I have died way too many times because it's unnecessarily clunky/difficult to jump over gaps/pits when you stand still near the edge. Jumping is too fast relative to the game mechanics. I don't even know how they muck up the combat considering you can only press ONE button to attack enemies (no down/up attacks). Combat is clunky in the sense that your melee range is tiny and you can't make ANY contact with enemies after hitting them or you lose a third of your HP. You maybe have 10 pixels of safety when you got to melee enemies. Hitboxes vs bosses (I only played one mini-boss but again if they can't even get that right then the rest of the game can't be much better) are a joke. The visual animation of the sword attack doesn't reflect the hitbox either. I was pretty excited for the death traps in the game but it's not what I expected. I was expecting that I would have to be aware at all times for any signs of traps but there is simply no way to know without dying or checking a playthrough. It makes the game unnecessarily repetitve because you get punished for things that are beyond your control which is not the "frustration" i look for when playing challenging platformers. One of the big flaws that essentially killed the game for me is the forced animation you get for picking items. You are forced to jump on the spot for about 30 seconds after getting a new item and imagine having to do that every time you die (which is very often). On top of it, the devs have joke based achievements related to death count when most of your deaths are from traps that you cannot fortell or because of terrible combat.If you liked Super Mario games, Sonic, Donkey Kong Country or Shovel Knight I would highly recommend that you don't get the game in it's current state. If the devs fix the movement and the combat I think it would be worth the 5 euros either way.

Posted: November 15, 2015
												Castle in the Darkness is an awesome throwback to NES era gaming! Its charming pixel graphics, and chip tune music complement the challenging platform jumping and tough boss fights. There are various enemies, and a ton of optional pickups. The game is riddled with fun cultural references; from Zelda, to Ghost and Goblins, to Little Shop of Horrors, every area presents something new, yet familiar. A must play for Metroidvania fans!

Posted: July 24, 2015
												Look, if you want to play a 2 button NES game then this is an OK one. That being said It needs a bit more, like the controler working off the bat, more options, sound maybe (im not sure if there is sound or not but there was none for me). Who make a game without sound? Multiple resolution support? The gameplay is OK, but I feel like it is geared towards the reaction time of the younger generation (Im and old 30 year old, lol). Yes you can memorize the fights and move on (in my 1 hourish played I already killed about 8 bosses) but its more frusterating that satisfying when you are forced to memorize things by repeatedly dieing. So rather than being skill and strategy based I feel this game is reaction time based, and memorizational.All that being said, I hope the Dev keeps at it. Even though this game is simply not one I will recommend to friends, I fell the dev will do much better on his next game, and I will glady give that a try. So much so that I will not ask for a refund simply to support him.

Posted: July 29, 2015
												Have you never heard of or played any of the following?Legend of ZeldaMetroidCastlevaniaMarioGhouls & Ghosts / Ghosts & GoblinsIf so, you'll enjoy this game's "originality"With enough enemies and ideas ripped from the above games and other sources to make one wonder how they haven't gotten sued for copyright, you'll get tired of this game quickly. Not to mention enough instant-death spikes to fill the Empire State Building placed in some of the most BS of areas, you'll get your death counter to the hundreds in under an hour. There are even spikes placed directly nest to save points, meaning you better remember to jump if you'r in a hurry, otherwise you'll have wasted another 10 seconds to die, see the death screen, and start over.  Many games nowadays want to be "NES hard," but this game is NES cheap. I regret getting it even during a half-off sale.

Posted: July 21, 2015
												This game is not worthy of being called a Metroidvania. Super Metroid, for instance, is not filled with instant-death spikes in the most assholish positions with a crappy jump and a slightly slippery character. Neither is Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, for that matter.Not only that, but the previous games have movement tech of some sort. Alucard could shield dash and do a wing smash while in bat form and Richter coud air slash/slide, for instance, but nothing of the sort in Castle in the Darkness. Maybe I just haven't found anything for that yet, but I doubt the game will give you anything interesting or cool like that since it seems to rely on navigating one-hit kill spikes a lot.Also, Castle in the Darkness likes to make a lot of references to better games:"My name is Bagu""It is dangerous to go alone"Blue arremersand what not,  so it ends up like a mess of bits and pieces of other games and has no spirit or character of its own. Devs really need to stop with this nonsense already. Guacemelee had its references, but it still had its own spirit and character,

Posted: July 11, 2015
												Overall, the game is good and worth playing if you're into this kind of thing; however, one thing I will note is that this game varies a lot in the quality department in almost every aspect.Take the music for instance -- The first area's music is so awful I had to mute it and put on gaming/chiptune mixes in the background.  Other songs range from decent to good but I don't appreciate all the musical references and nods to other games such as the beginning of one of the songs having the same beginning that the Final Fantasy I battle music has.  When I die I have to hear that again and again and it gets obnoxious really fast.  One or two other songs have this problem as well.  After teleporting around and backtracking became a thing, I just disabled the music altogether since I was tired of hearing the songs I didn't like.  This is odd to me since with most 8-bit / indie / retro style games I usually like a majority of the soundtrack.  Anyway, at minimum an option to not restart the song from the beginning upon death would be nice.The enemies are mostly all well designed with some quite good variety in them.  The weapons and magic are all pretty good, fun to use, well designed, and well placed in the environment.  Also, huge props for birdbro (the bird magic where a bird follows you around).  I love birds and this put a huge smile on my face.  I traveled with birdbro almost at all times.Most of the bosses are too easy and/or have too few moves.  Many bosses only have 1 or 2 attacks that they do over and over.  Just a single extra way of attacking for every single boss would be a MASSIVE improvement.  The later bosses (last 1/3rd of the game) tend to have more moves and are more challenging and are a joy to play, but many of the earlier ones are a bit too simple.  Still fun, still good, just feeling a bit lacking.  Also a significant number of them I was able to exploit and kill them just by being close and mashing sword button as fast as I could ignoring damage I was taking or by using a ranged weapon.Finally, the level design.  Most areas have good level design and some areas have very solid level design; but, some areas have outright terrible or even unforgivable level design.  Having a spike trap and/or spike pit be unavoidable is just bull.  If you don't already know something is a trap, there is no way to avoid death in some instances.  Granted, many locations it's hinted at and woks well; however, others it's not.  For example, the 3 Mario pipes you can choose from to enter Glitch City.  Two of them are guaranteed death with no way of knowing.  Terrible level design.  Wasting my time having to walk back over there three times.  That happens too often in this game.  Also, rewarding the player for finding a hidden alcove while jumping down into a sure-kill spike pit by trapping them in an inescapable way and giving them useless "troll armor" and "troll weapon" is completely asinine.  The player must kill themselves and has no options.  Yes, some people might find it funny that the developer "trolled" the player.  Other people, myself included, see this as terrible taste in humor and feel insulted in a won't-be-buying-any-more-games-from-you-if-you-keep-this♥♥♥♥♥♥up-you-cheeky-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ kind of way.  Butthurt or not, it's bad level design.  I also really hate the many areas that you have to essentially go through twice to obtain an item: once to the item, then once to get back to the save point so you can save and keep the item.  This is especially bad for difficult locations where it's painful enough just going through one way.  The well designed areas which do this have different challenges depending on which direction you're traveling, but many later on tend to be a second verbatim repeat of the same exact pixel-perfect double jumps required of the player and they get really old really fast.  I hate it when games have the expectation of pixel perfect jumps from platform to platform but do not incorporate any kind of edge falloff jump rescue grace window.  Basically, you need to jump at the last possible split second right before your character falls off the platform they are running on in order to get enough distance to make it to the next platform or over the spikes; however, since the player is optimizing their jump timing towards that very last split second the tendency is to jump too late -- once the player has already started to fall off the platform.  Most of the time, this manifests itself by the player as "wtf, what happened to my second jump" because the first jump is lost once the character is past the edge.  Good games I have seen incorporate a tiny grace window after a character has gotten past the platform that is pretty much unnoticeable without a frame by frame where the player can jump as if they were still on the platform.  The way this game behaves sometimes makes me feel like I'm playing IWBTG again.  That game looooves eating 2nd jumps.Anyway, I really do tend to focus on the things I didn't like and only gloss over the things I did like when writing reviews and I want to make it clear that I do recommend this game and believe it to be mostly solid.  But, if you like a consistently good gaming experience from start to end, you're gonna have to look elsewhere.

Posted: July 23, 2015
												This game isn't downright bad, it just isn't especially good. Some complaints I have about it are certain aspects are a little buggy (e.g. it was very easy to get stuck inside the gears in the clock tower), and the hitboxes are quite a bit larger than the actual models. I've been hit many times when I though I wasn't close enough, and the sword reaches quite a bit farther than the animation suggests. Additionally, enemies deal a lot of damage, so it kind of makes me wonder why I have so many HP in the first place, but I guess that's also made up for with the frequent save/recovery points.To be completely honest, I can't think of any especially good points about the game. It plays just like you'd expect any other retro platformer to play. Granted, I haven't completed the game yet, so there may be other mechanics in the game that I am not yet aware of, but it's pretty much a standard platformer.All in all if you love platformers like I do, then go ahead, give it a try, but if you're not specifically into the retro platformer genre, then I don't see much reason to pick up this game.

												Amazing metroidvania title that has all the right things:Spells, abilities, weapons, armor, charged attacks, hidden treasure, platforming, and TONS of boss fights.This game is very challenging and unforgiving, but offers up rewards around every corner to keep you firing away at that impossible platforming section or boss fight over and over again.As of the time of this review (Feb 16, 2015) the game has some bugs that make it impossible for me to get 100% completion. Posted: February 9, 2015
												Enjoyable quirky game. The old school influence is obvious, both in graphics/audio and gameplay.  That said, there are some issues. A lot can be written off as design decisions (like not being able to attack while moving), but the game is diffuclt, not because of how hard it is but because it lacks certain polish. Menus are slow performing and not all controls are clear (like pause as p and fullsreen as f), Attack range is shorter than it should be to start out making some easy enemies needlessly hard. Audio is hit or miss a lot of time, and starting with a default 0 level for volume leads to a bit of confusion.  Overall the game gets a recommendation because it is a good game, but it could have been truly great with some polish.

Posted: February 14, 2015
												Let's get the good stuff out of the way first: the graphics are awesome, the music is wonderful and the boss battles are great. That being said, this game has one enormous flaw: it's punishing rather than challenging.The first few levels are extremely deceptive in that the jumping puzzles are short, easy and require minimal retries to complete. Later levels are so difficult that some of them require SURGICAL PRECISION in order to beat them. The difficulty curve is so steep that at one point I got stuck on a level and revisited every area before it five times because I thought I was missing an item that I needed in order to continue.Later levels also take away save points before the level's boss. So for some levels you actually have to run a gauntlet of enemies, spikes and jumping puzzles just to get to the boss and you'd better hope you have enough health to beat it or it's right back to the beginning of the gauntlet. Eventually, the level design becomes so incredibly difficult that beating them becomes a matter of luck. And, frankly, that should be enough for me to hate this game with every fiber of my being so intensely that it reverberates throughout the universe and destroys many small planets.So why am I recommending this game given how much I despise the level design? Well, because everything else is really, really good. I loved the early levels. I loved the references (even the ones that killed me.)  I loved the boss battles and the graphics and the music and everything else. Every area that didn't suffer from the bad level design felt awesome and fun. If the game gave you the option of skipping the difficult precision based jumping puzzles it would be perfect, but as is it's a pretty good game that suffers due to a few extremely bad levels.Buy it if you want, but be warned that you will grow to hate it.Update: Having played further, it turns out I was missing items (once again) at the places where I was having trouble advancing. Not ability enhancing items, but armor. Having done some experimenting, it seems like wearing different armor affects your speed and, possibly, double jump height. Certain jumps are impossible in some sets of armor, but are possible in others. This is never adressed in game and it isn't very apparent, but the results speak for themselves.Do I still think the level design is bad? A little less so now, but yeah. Some of the sections I encountered after further exploration were just ridiculous. And yes, some of them do still rely on luck (for most people.) So I get the feeling a lot of people (the people who actually stick with it to the end,  that is) are going to be stuck with the "bad ending", because some of the levels are simply too frustrating to complete.But again, it is still good and I do still recommend it.

Posted: February 15, 2015
												Great all around game. Read another review where someone said it was more Sega Master System than Nintendo. To that I say no way. This game has the color palette and background style made standard for the NES. If anything it's 8 parts NES and 2 parts TurboGrafx16 (mostly in terms of performance).This game will♥♥♥♥♥♥you off... but the challenges are not the hardest. It's more so, die, find out why, repeat (although not always)... so what's complicated is having to repeat some areas, due to checkpoint, and then dying on something very simple as you attempt to rush through it. This is something that you'll be aware of in SMB. Good news is, the more you play through said area, the easy it gets. This sounds obvious, but more so, you'll learn the exact method to attack (more obvious in SMB). Once you nail that, you should be gold.There are references to other games... and the only time I like it is when it referenced BOI. I wish all the characters were original, because this game delivers, and I want to know more about the world, and hopefully a sequel or spinoff.The style:- Keith Courage in Alpha Zone (TurboGrafx16).- Cave Story- Zelda 2The Pros:- Great Art- Metroidvania- moments of major accomplishment- very very fun and rewarding- retro done rightThe Cons:- UI is mostly controlled by keyboard (Pause, etc)- UI for selecting inventory is only done at checkpoints, and also is awkward (no back out, have to reselect item if you happen to go into the menu to see what else there is)- Checkpoint before everyboss, you have to then backtrack to save after boss, or you lose your progress (not that far, but sort of annoying). Another checkpoint per boss would have been awesome.- Warp system kind of confusing.

Posted: February 22, 2015
												Well, what can I say?I'm having a good time playing this game.It start harder than hard, but then you get used to mechanics and wow, it's amazing.Cool graphics and music. Loads of bosses and challenges. Nice scenaries.Our main character is becoming a total badass, storywise.Totally worthy of money paid. Posted: February 9, 2015
												Another great throwback game with plenty of references to classic metroidvania games notably Symphony of the Night. And music that sounds a lot like Mega Man, chiptune and all. I swear it is equally good to say the Mega Man 2 or 3 soundtrack (the best in the series). And the character is actually blue as well for obvious reasons.This has got some of the most fluid platforming in any recent 8-bit style game.  Jumping is not stiff and you can get in a great groove just jumping and killing rinse repeat. It is almost hypnotic in this game. Be prepared to die a lot. And I mean a lot. 2 hours played and already died over 100 times. But this game will not make you rage quit. Why because save points are fairly frequent. Frankly the game is almost old school NES "lite".  Maybe I just am used to how punishing old school NES games can be (Ninja Gaiden, anyone?). This game is tame compared to Mega Man.Another great feature is that bosses are frequent and many. If you like simple boss battles you will love this. It is almost like a boss gauntlet. And there are some bosses that will seem familiar. You will know what I mean. A hero frog that uncannily seems like the one from Chrono Trigger? lol. With a slurping tongue to boot. My only complaint is no map but this is to be expected because most 8-bit games did not have a map feature. And the levels are pretty much easy to navigate and remember. Only other complaint is back tracking seems a bit annoying I have yet to find keys for the first area and I am already way past it. There are also many optional side areas you will miss unless you really watch for those breakable walls. There are many and they are usually noticeable. Usually you get a valuable new weapon or item out of this careful exploration. And the areas are usually a big step up in challenge for what you get out of them. They are worth exploring even if you die a lot on them.

Posted: February 9, 2015
												When I first seen the game I knew it would be something I would enjoy. If you're into old school retro platformer/metriodvania type games then this game is up your alley. It's extremely fast pace and punishing, but its always moving forward and trying to teach you lessons that will last throughout the game. You can choose to power through the whole game and have a harder time or you can take your time and explore and find all the secrets the game has within it. The game always has a way to make yourself stronger if you're having trouble with a boss, or you can try to skill your way through it. Another great addition is the music. It fits every area and when you get into a boss fight the music gets you pumped up and excited. Overall the game is extremely enjoyable and you will love every second you're playing it.My only issues with the game are: It needs a map system. There are a lot of secret areas/items and when you're back tracking trying to find certain rooms its extremely easy to get lost unless you spend a lot of time searching. The game flows so fast that this issue is easily ignorable. Tthe game lacks identity. It spends so much time mimicing other games that it fails to deveop into its own style. A lot of people will compare this game to X or Y and thats how you know its lacking something to make it unique. It almost made it there on its own, but it didn't make it.At the end of the day these issues are anything but game killing. If you're wondering if you should get this game you need to go and buy it right now. You will not regret it.

Posted: November 11, 2015
												Castle in the Darkness is a pretty good metroidvania style game with tight controls.  The main character walks pretty fast so platforming can get pretty tricky.  If you are like me, the vast majority of your deaths will be spike related.  Spikes are everywhere in this game and they deal instant death. Also, in new game +, remember when you get new armor to equip it and then re-equip the frog suit. Oh, and the troll armor and the troll sword is the dev trolling you if you encounter these items.

Posted: July 25, 2015
												I've played this game only for a few hours... But let me tell you; as far as retro-looking games go, this has got to be near the top. The game is just right. Platforming feels natural after a few minutes, the fighting is as simple as it gets, often with the Megaman mentality where you'd rather charge your spell than fight with a weapon.This game is amazing.Its pros far outweigh the cons, no matter how you look at it. From the music to the atmosphere, this game is really good.And as far as I'm concerned, the only real "cons" it has is the back and forth. That is the one thing I can't say I miss from old school games. I've never been a big fan or revisiting areas that I'm far too strong for just to find an older place that kicked me where it hurts the first time I saw it. So if you can't remember exactly where everything is, it can get very tedious. But the game is still fun so... Not that big a deal. :P8/10

Posted: July 25, 2015
												tl;dr: This game is very challenging, but it's a lot of fun if you stick with it.Fundamentally, CitD is an old-school 2D platformer in the Metroidvania style. The story is paper-thin, but you're not playing it for the gripping plot: you're playing because the game offers hardcore challenges that never stop coming. Make no mistake: this game is hard. Be prepared to die a lot every time you enter a new area. If the enemies don't get you, there's no shortage of instant-death spikes that will. Still, if you have the patience to learn each new area and keep practicing until you can make every jump, there's a lot of cool stuff to find. The world is pretty big overall; I've seen bigger, but there's definitely enough area to keep you going for quite a few hours. Nearly every area has something new to find if you come back with later upgrades (particularly the double-jump), and it's very hard to find everything a given zone has to offer on the first run through.The bosses range from trivial to excruciatingly hard. Some of them went down on the first or second try (even relatively late in the game), while some of them took me days to beat. I do wish the difficulty curve was a bit smoother for some of the bosses, and there are a couple bosses that are all but impossible to beat without specific items or spells, which feels like it could be fairer. Still, none of them are truly impossible (especially if you find every single upgrade possible), and it's really satisfying to beat one that's been giving you hell. (Just make sure that you save immediately afterward!)The game is jam-packed with references to other games (mostly classic, but some more recent). I don't really consider this to be especially good or bad; it can be entertaining to see references you recognize, but the game seems to hardly have anything that isn't inspired by something else, so it can get a little tiresome. (Some of the references are really darn obscure, too—I was expecting the Zelda references and the Castlevania references, but I was shocked to see a reference to Magic Sword, the 1992 Capcom game on the SNES.) They're cute if you like that sort of thing, but they can get old even if you get most of them. Still, I wouldn't count this as a reason not to play the game.There are some places where the game lacks polish. If there's a way to pause (especially while using a controller), I haven't found it, which just seems like a huge oversight. There's no map screen or minimap, so you have to have a pretty good memory if you want to remember where all the alternate paths lead (or where you need to come back to once you have more mobility upgrades). While none of the challenges are downright unfair (in the style of, for example, I Wanna Be The Guy), some of them can feel a little underhanded if you're not prepared for them. You do collect gold to buy upgrades, but the opportunities to spend money don't come evenly; you have quite a few at the beginning, and then you go for the bulk of the game before you find the next ones, which feels choppy. There's basically no invulnerability period after taking damage, so if you're used to having a chance to get away from danger that way, you might be in for a rude awakening. And like I said, some of the bosses will have you tearing your hair out, especially if you haven't found every single upgrade possible. Finally, the final boss is really disappointing (I beat him on the first or second try, no problem), which feels like a letdown after such a challenging game. (Yes, I know that I just said that some bosses are too hard, and then I complained that the final boss is too easy. My point is that the curve is off.)Overall, though, I really enjoyed this game. It really is punishingly hard, but there's no part of it that's truly impossible. It's challenging from the get-go and never lets up, but with the exception of one or two bosses, there's never a crazy difficulty spike that makes you feel like you've hit a wall. Aside from the lack of an accessible pause button, the controls are simple and responsive, It's hard enough to make me feel challenged, but it's got enough hidden items (and even just save points) to continually reward you for trying. If you grew up on 2D platformers and you're willing to practice a new one until you master it, you can have a lot of fun with Castle in the Darkness. I recommend it.

Posted: July 27, 2015
												I think is the most authentic modern-retro game that I own.  Sadly, the term "retro" is thrown around much too often in the Steam store.  The term is sometimes used as a cover for bad graphics and simple gameplay.  Sometimes you have games that try to be "retro" but without understanding retro gaming and what made it great.  Take some sprite graphics, throw it into a half-decent platform engine, throw in some tough enemies, and whammo you have yourself a "retro" game – or do you?  Such games fail to grasp what made retro gaming great.  Difficulty was never the goal, it's more of a side effect that sometimes happens when you get the recipe right.  It takes some good level design, some unique and interesting enemies, good boss fights, and excellent controls.  Castle In The Darkness has all of these in spades.  Clearly the biggest influence here has been Castlevania, visually inspired by the 8bit games, controls inspired by the more fluid movements of SotN and the handheld games that succeeded it.  Even the name of the game is a nod to Castlevania.  The game is hard, yes, but fair.  The enemies are strong but consistent and predictable, you need to use reflexes but also strategy to survive.  The mood and tone of the game hits a balance somewhere between 8bit Castlevania and 8bit Link/Zelda.  The NPCs are spot-on and run the full gamut from helpful to cryptic, hilarious, or useless.  The controls are tight, the combat is fast but not frantic, the platforming skill needed is moderate for most of the game, though a few sections do require extreme precision.  You put all of this together and you have one of the most authentic retro gaming experiences on Steam right now.  You will die, you will die a lot, but you'll never get stuck for long in the same place, and when you beat that boss or hit that save point, you will feel a true sense of accomplishment that's often lacking from modern games.  I think this game would have fit right in on NES or SMS and I think it would have been well received at the time by critics and gamers alike.  Back in the NES days, I would have spent $6 just to rent a game like this for two nights, so to be able to buy it for that price, I think that's a great deal.

Posted: June 26, 2016
												This game is essentially a love letter to the 8bit era. Tons of references and call-outs to oldschool games and even 80's pop culture if you have a keen eye (in the room where you find the ares gauntlet there's a giant painting of vigo the carpathian on the wall).There's an area that's clearly inspired by the clocktower in Castlevania, and you fight a mini-boss that borders on infringement-territory with taito's bubble bobble.All of this is to say that Castle in the Darkness clearly knows its audience and isn't afraid to play fan service. It has pretty solid platforming, lots of criss-crossing and back-tracking, RPG mechanics like inns and shops, and everything else you'd expect from a game that's trying to harness the power of the 80's.So yes- thumbs up, buy this game and enjoy it if these are the types of things that you enjoy. However, there are some negative things to point out.First, this game is pretty rough around the edges. Gamepad support is barely there, and menus are never fully navigable using only a gamepad (you always end up having to go back to the keyboard for something) which means you likely won't be enjoying this game from your couch in big picture mode.Second, the resolution options for this game are abhorrent. It starts up in windowed mode- a TINY window, which almost makes sense given that it's a pixel-game. You are provided with a handful of scale-factors to choose from, which also makes sense given that you want to keep square pixels for an authentic experience. What does not make sense is the fact that everything is scaled bilinearly, which means everything gets blurry as♥♥♥♥♥♥ Why didn't they provide an option for nearest neighbor scaling to keep the pixel art nice and sharp? The developers of this game need to go play Shovel Knight and see how a retro game can be developed for modern hardware and still keep its authenticity.Aside from those two major issues, everything else I've encountered is fairly minor.

Posted: May 18, 2015
												Castle in the Darkness is one of those games that some people will love, a game clearly inspired by Zelda could be appreciated as a throwback to fairly hard platforming. Other people simply won’t have the patience that you need when you’re playing this game, especially if you haven’t played many platformers. This is your typical new Mario platformer. This is almost a pixelated 2-d version of dark souls.  Clearly my nearing of 600 deaths will show you that I was not prepared in many ways for this game. This however doesn’t mean it’s a terrible game. The game starts you off with a fairly plain story. The king of the land has fallen ill, and in his weakened state monsters attack the kingdom. All the castle guards are defeated besides you! So you go off on a journey through the kingdom to save the princess and the king. Of course if you’re playing this game it isn’t for the story so it’s good enough to get you out and exploring. So what can your little knight do? He can jump a use a sword. The first bit of the game for me was getting used to how my characters hit boxes were and how far the sword could swing out. Literally if something hits the feather of your helmet it will damage you. Throughout your adventure you will acquire new weapons, armor, and magical abilities to improve your chances of survival. 1 thing the game could have added to help would be a map. Many parts of the game require you to go back and use new abilities like double jump to find hidden areas and gain new powers. If rather few teleport areas in the game it would have been nice to have a map to make sure I was done looking everywhere rather than traversing the entire map only to find out I might have missed one turn somewhere. Without backtracking with new found abilities this game will be a lot harder than it already is. If they were going to rename this game they should call it The castle of trial and error because that is what you will be doing most of this game. If you don’t get in the habit of saving right after you kill a boss that took you 20 deaths to beat you will find yourself facing it again if you die before the next save point. If the bosses don’t irritate you the instant deaths of spikes will. Spikes are used in this game to much for my liking. You will learn to cautiously approach every room because many deaths will result in unexpected spike deaths or not jumping the correct way, and it is because of that fact I recommend playing this with a controller. Trying to jump through death traps with the keyboard could be rather frustrating at times. The variations of enemies is astounding in this game. You will learn how to approach all of them after a couple encounters fairly easily. Bosses require skilled timing and memorization. After realizing how to defeat a boss the pattern might seem fairly simple. If you don’t have the right weapon however the task can be very agitating. After beating bosses though you will be filled if a huge feeling of relief and you will rush cautiously back to the last save point so you don’t have to do the encounter again. The soundtrack fit the game perfectly and I wish I could enjoy it more if I wasn’t constantly hearing the small tone that plays after you die. Overall the game has a super large variety of enemies and bosses for players to face off against, there is no lack of content to be found here. The soundtrack fit this game perfectly. However lack of a map made backtracking a hassle and spikes felt slightly over used for my taste. If you’re into a nice challenging platformer then this might be what you’re looking for. If you don’t have a lot of patience, aren’t that good at platforming maybe you should pass this one up and come back to it later on.
